body:
Type aliasing and package management are two different things. One is a
change to the langauge, the other is a change to a tool that drives the
compilation process. Please don't conflate the two, or it'll be the ruin of
them both.

On Tue, 13 Sep 2016, 02:58 Felix Lange <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> A positive aspect that might be obvious to some, but wasn't to me
> initially: this proposal partially solves the 'vendoring edge case'. To
> recap with a concrete example
>
> package fooclient
> import "github.com/x/net/websocket" // vendored alongside package fooclient
> func DialWebsocket(b websocket.Config) *Connection { ... }
>
> The caller of DialWebsocket cannot construct websocket.Config because it
> cannot refer to it (vendored packages cannot be imported). There are a few
> ways around this problem right now, without type aliases:
>
>    - don't use imported types in API surface (not always possible)
>    - provide wrapper definitions (inconvenient, limiting)
>    - limit use of vendoring
>
> Aliases provide a workaround: package fooclient would declare aliases for
> websocket.Config which the caller can refer to. In this particular case, a
> suitable alias definition might be:
>
> package fooclient
> import "github.com/x/net/websocket" // vendored alongside package fooclient
> type WebsocketConfig => websocket.Configfunc NewWebsocketConfig => websocket.NewConfig
> func DialWebsocket(b *WebsocketConfig) *Conn { ... }
>
> I'm not even sure myself whether this is a good or bad use of aliases. One
> nice aspect is that package fooclient stays in control of the exported API.
> On the flip side, readability is hindered because it is not clear what a
> WebsocketConfig actually consists of.
